Let $h(n)$ be such that every graph on $n$ vertices with $>n^2/4$ many edges contains a triangle whose vertices have degrees summing to at least $h(n)$. Estimate $h(n)$. In particular, is it true that\[h(n)\geq (2(\sqrt{3}-1)-o(1))n?\]



Erd\H{o}s and Laskar \cite{ErLa85} proved\[2(\sqrt{3}-1)n \geq h(n) \geq (1+c)n\]for some $c>0$. The lower bound was improved to $\frac{21}{16}n$ by Fan \cite{Fa88}.




References


[ErLa85] Erd\H{o}s, Paul and Laskar, Renu, A note on the size of a chordal subgraph. Congr. Numer. (1985), 81--86.

[Fa88] Fan, Genghua, Degree sum for a triangle in a graph. J. Graph Theory (1988), 249--263.
